mentions.context: DeepMedic: This method is based on an 11-layers deep dual pathway 3D CNN designed for brain lesion segmentation.
DeepMedic comes last with a submission score of 90.866.
DeepMedic consistency index fluctuates from 0.49 to 0.602.
nicMSlesion: This method is based on a cascade of two 3D patch-wise CNNs.
nicMSlesion is the least consistent with scores ranging from 0.177 to 0.512.
DeepLesionBrain is a deep learning framework for MS lesion segmentation designed for domain generalization.
DeepLesionBrain (DLB) refers to using our spatially distributed specialized networks, each network in charge of segmenting a sub-volume.

We chose to compare our method with three state-of-the-art approaches: nicMSlesion [37], DeepMedic [22], and 2.5D Tiramisu [41].

First, when trained on ISBI dataset, the segmentations of 2.5D Tiramisu, DeepMedic, and DLB are more accurate than nicMSlesion segmentation, although all techniques missed a large portion of the central lesion (False Negative) located around the midsagittal plane.
In this case, DLB obtained the best score of 0.647, followed by 2.5D Tiramisu and DeepMedic with 0.6261 and 0.602 respectively.
Especially in the case of small lesions, DLB missed only one lesion, whereas both nicMSlesion and 2.5 D Tiramissu missed four lesions, and DeepMedic misses two lesions.
We chose to compare our method with three state-of-the-art approaches: nicMSlesion [37], DeepMedic [22], and 2.5D Tiramisu [41].
The experiments have been performed with Keras 2.2.4 [8] and Tensorflow 1.12.0 [1] on NVIDIA Titan Xp 12 GB GPU.

These networks are loaded one by one to enable the use of a common GPU hardware solution (e.g., NVIDIA Titan Xp with 12 GB in our setup).
DLB obtained a hybrid score of 0.697 while nicMSlesion obtained 0.669, 2.5D Tiramisu obtained 0.664, and DeepMedic obtained the lowest score of 0.597.
On our in-house dataset, DLB performed significantly better with a hybrid score of 0.696 while 2.5D Tiramisu, DeepMedic, and nicMSlesion obtained respectively 0.654, 0.523, and 0.419.
We notice that DLB obtains the highest hybrid score and Dice index by a large margin compared to 2.5D tiramisu, DeepMedic, and nicMSlesion.
In this case, we obtained close consistency scores for 2.5D Tiramisu and DLB with Dice scores around 0.72 while DeepMedic and nicMSlesion are less consistent with 0.537 and 0.514 respectively.

First, when trained on ISBI dataset, the segmentations of 2.5D Tiramisu, DeepMedic, and DLB are more accurate than nicMSlesion segmentation, although all techniques missed a large portion of the central lesion (False Negative) located around the midsagittal plane.
2.5D Tiramisu [41] is the best-ranked method with the current highest ISBI Score of 93.21, followed in second place by nnUnet [21] with 93.09.

Although reference methods have been originally proposed with a specific number of modalities (i.e., Tiramisu 2.5D and nicMSlesion were tested with 4 and 3 modalities respectively), their implementation is independent of the number of modalities since all modalities are concatenated and fed to the CNN.
The three approaches give close results with submission scores of 92.923 for 2.5D Tiramisu, 92.849 for DLB, and 92.161 for nicMSlesion.
On our in-house dataset, DLB performed significantly better with a hybrid score of 0.696 while 2.5D Tiramisu, DeepMedic, and nicMSlesion obtained respectively 0.654, 0.523, and 0.419.
In this case, we obtained close consistency scores for 2.5D Tiramisu and DLB with Dice scores around 0.72 while DeepMedic and nicMSlesion are less consistent with 0.537 and 0.514 respectively.
We notice that DLB obtains the highest hybrid score and Dice index by a large margin compared to 2.5D tiramisu, DeepMedic, and nicMSlesion.

Second, when validating on ISBI, the obtained submission score is 89.043 for DLB (the closest to human performance), 87.344 for DeepMedic, 87.173 for nicMSlesion, and 86.686 for 2.5D Tiramisu (the farthest from human performance).

We verified the average inference time per image for each method on the same machine and the same preprocessed images: 57.353s for nicMSlesion, 17.547s for DeepMedic, 47.471s for 2.5D Tiramisu, and 38.014s for DLB (this time does not include image preprocessing).
Especially in the case of small lesions, DLB missed only one lesion, whereas both nicMSlesion and 2.5 D Tiramissu missed four lesions, and DeepMedic misses two lesions.

Second, when validating on ISBI, the obtained submission score is 89.043 for DLB (the closest to human performance), 87.344 for DeepMedic, 87.173 for nicMSlesion, and 86.686 for 2.5D Tiramisu (the farthest from human performance).

We verified the average inference time per image for each method on the same machine and the same preprocessed images: 57.353s for nicMSlesion, 17.547s for DeepMedic, 47.471s for 2.5D Tiramisu, and 38.014s for DLB (this time does not include image preprocessing).

When validating the methods on MSSEG'16, we report that 2.5D Tiramisu obtained slightly better results (not significantly) than DLB, in terms of hybrid score whereas nicMSlesion and DeepMedic performed relatively worse with 0.537 and 0.51 respectively.
Instead of proposing another improvement of the segmentation accuracy, we propose a novel method robust to domain shift and performing well on unseen datasets, called DeepLesionBrain (DLB).

When validating the methods on MSSEG'16, we report that 2.5D Tiramisu obtained slightly better results (not significantly) than DLB, in terms of hybrid score whereas nicMSlesion and DeepMedic performed relatively worse with 0.537 and 0.51 respectively.

Second, we notice that our approach obtained a significantly higher hybrid score when validating on the ISBI testing dataset, with a submission score of 89.843 compared to 2.5 Tiramisu, DeepMedic, and nicMSlesion with 89.289, 86.810, and 84.512 respectively.

First, the obtained results when testing on MSSEG'16 indicates a close segmentation accuracy for DLB and 2.5D Tiramisu in terms of hybrid score (0.745 and 0.741) and slightly lower performance from nicMSlesion and DeepMedic (0.7 and 0.717).
